Let’s use a built-in method to define and solve the initial-value problem

children.html: u′=sin⁡[(u+t)2],t∈[0,4],u(0)=−1.u'=\sin[(u+t)^2], \quad t \in [0,4], \quad u(0)=-1.u′=sin[(u+t)2],t∈[0,4],u(0)=−1.

uuu

These ingredients are supplied to a solver function. A standard first choice of solver is called

[t, u] = ode45(f, [0, 4], u0);
fprintf("length(t) = %d, length(u) = %d\n", length(t), length(u))
The solution is represented as a pair of vectors,
contains the times at which the solution was computed and

children.html: u(t)u(t)u(t)

children.value:
clf
plot(t, u, '-o')
xlabel("t")
ylabel("u(t)")
title(("Solution of an IVP"));

You might want to know the solution at particular times other than the ones selected by the solver. That requires an interpolation. To do this automatically requires calling the solver with just one output argument, which is then supplied to
to evaluate the solution at any time.

children.html: u′=(u+t)2u'=(u+t)^2u′=(u+t)2

data.name: stderr
data.text: Warning: Failure at t=7.853789e-01.  Unable to meet integration tolerances without reducing the step size below the smallest value allowed (1.776357e-15) at time t.

children.value: The warning message we received can mean that there is a bug in the formulation of the problem. But if everything has been done correctly, it suggests that the solution simply may not exist past the indicated time. This is a possibility in nonlinear

clf
semilogy(t, u)
xlabel("t")
ylabel("u(t)")
title(("Finite-time blowup"));

u′=−uu'=-uu′=−u
∂f/∂u=±1\partial f/\partial u = \pm 1∂f/∂u=±1

children.value: , so the condition number bound from

children.value: in both problems. However, they behave quite differently. In the case of exponential growth,

children.html: u′=uu'=uu′=u

children.value: , the bound is the actual condition number.

clf
for u0 = [0.7, 1, 1.3]    % initial values
    fplot(@(t) exp(t) * u0, [0, 3]), hold on
end
xlabel('t')
ylabel('u(t)')
title(('Exponential divergence of solutions'));

children.html: u′=−uu'=-uu′=−u

children.value: , solutions actually get closer together with time.

clf
for u0 = [0.7, 1, 1.3]    % initial values
    fplot(@(t) exp(-t) * u0, [0, 3]), hold on
end
xlabel('t')
ylabel('u(t)')
title(('Exponential convergence of solutions'));
In this case the actual condition number is one, because the initial difference between solutions is the largest over all time. Hence the exponentially growing bound

children.html: eb−ae^{b-a}eb−a
u′=sin⁡[(u+t)2],t∈[0,4],u(0)=−1.u'=\sin[(u+t)^2], \quad t \in [0,4], \quad u(0)=-1.u′=sin[(u+t)2],t∈[0,4],u(0)=−1.

children.value: As usual, we need to define the function for the right-hand side of the
, the interval for the independent variable, and the initial value.

We could define a different interpolant to get a smoother picture above, but the derivation of Euler’s method assumed a piecewise linear interpolant, and that sets the limit of its accuracy. We can instead request more steps to make the interpolant look smoother.

children.html: nnn

children.value: changed the solution noticeably. Since we know that interpolants and finite differences become more accurate as

children.html: h→0h\to 0h→0

children.value: , we should anticipate the same behavior from Euler’s method. We don’t have an exact solution to compare to, so we will use a built-in solver to construct an accurate reference solution.
Now we can perform a convergence study.
The error is approximately cut by a factor of 10 for each increase in

children.html: nnn

children.value: by the same factor. A log-log plot also confirms first-order convergence. Keep in mind that since

children.html: h=(b−a)/nh=(b-a)/nh=(b−a)/n
O(h)=O(n−1)O(h)=O(n^{-1})O(h)=O(n−1)

children.value:
clf
loglog(n, err, 'o-')
hold on, loglog(n, 0.5 * err(end) * (n / n(end)).^(-1), '--')
xlabel('n')
ylabel('inf-norm error')
title('Convergence of Euler''s method')
legend('error', 'O(n^{-1})', 'location', 'southwest');
We encode the predator–prey equations via a function, defined here externally.
are parameters that influence the solution of the
, so the function signature above includes a third argument for them. But the solvers we use expect to receive a function of

children.html: ttt
u\mathbf{u}u

children.value: only. To deal with this, we create a function handle
that captures the parameter values in its definition.

params = [0.1, 0.25];
f = @(t, u) f63_predprey(t, u, params);
. If we later want to change the values of the parameters, we have to redefine
We use a new syntax here for calling
. By giving it a vector as the
argument, we are asking it to return the solution at the times in that vector.

u0 = [1; 0.01];    % column vector
a = 0; b = 60;     % time interval

[t, u] = ode45(f, linspace(a, b, 1001), u0);
size(u)
from the output is the solution vector

to find the solution (although it does not allow us to choose different time nodes for the output).
Notice above that the accuracy of the Euler solution deteriorates rapidly.

As time progresses, the point in the phase plane spirals inward toward a limiting closed loop called a

children.value: Let’s implement the coupled pendulums from
. The pendulums will be pulled in opposite directions and then released together from rest.
First we check the behavior of the system when the pendulums are uncoupled, i.e., when

children.html: k=0k=0k=0

children.value: is used below to restrict output to just

children.html: u1u_1u1​
u2u_2u2​

children.value: You can see that the pendulums swing independently:
Because the model is nonlinear and the initial angles are not small, they have slightly different periods of oscillation, and they go in and out of phase.
With coupling activated, a different behavior is seen.
The coupling makes the pendulums swap energy back and forth:

children.html: u′=sin⁡[(u+t)2],t∈[0,4],u(0)=−1.u'=\sin[(u+t)^2], \quad t \in [0,4], \quad u(0)=-1.u′=sin[(u+t)2],t∈[0,4],u(0)=−1.

children.value: We use a built-in solver to construct an accurate approximation to the exact solution.
Now we perform a convergence study of our two Runge–Kutta implementations.
The amount of computational work at each time step is assumed to be proportional to the number of stages. Let’s compare on an apples-to-apples basis by using the number of

children.html: fff

children.value:
clf, loglog([2*n 4*n], err, '-o')
hold on
loglog(2*n, 1e-5 * (n / n(end)) .^ (-2), '--')
loglog(4*n, 1e-10 * (n / n(end)) .^ (-4), '--')
xlabel("f-evaluations");  ylabel("inf-norm error")
title("Convergence of RK methods")
legend("IE2", "RK4", "O(n^{-2})", "O(n^{-4})", "location", "southwest");
The fourth-order variant is more efficient in this problem over a wide range of accuracy.

children.html: u′=et−usin⁡uu'=e^{t-u\sin u}u′=et−usinu

children.value: The solution makes a very abrupt change near

children.html: t=2.4t=2.4t=2.4

children.value: . The resulting time steps vary over three orders of magnitude.
If we had to run with a uniform step size to get this accuracy, it would be
On the other hand, the average step size that was actually taken was
We took fewer steps by a factor of almost 1000! Even accounting for the extra stage per step and the occasional rejected step, the savings are clear.
that appears to blow up in a finite amount of time. Because the solution increases so rapidly as it approaches the blowup, adaptive stepping is required even to get close.

data.name: stderr
data.text: Warning: Stepsize too small near t=0.785409.

children.value: In fact, the failure of the adaptivity gives a decent idea of when the singularity occurs.

clf, semilogy(t, u)
xlabel("t");  ylabel("u(t)")
title("Adaptive solution near a singularity")

tf = t(end);
xline(tf, "linestyle", "--")
text(tf, 1e5, sprintf(" t = %.6f ", tf))
We study the convergence of AB4 using the

children.html: u′=sin⁡[(u+t)2]u'=\sin[(u+t)^2]u′=sin[(u+t)2]
0≤t≤40\le t \le 40≤t≤4
u(0)=−1u(0)=-1u(0)=−1

children.value: . As usual, a built-in solver is called to give an accurate reference solution.
Now we perform a convergence study of the AB4 code.

children.html: O(h4)O(h^4)O(h4)

children.value: , so a log-log scale is appropriate for the errors.

clf, loglog(n, err, '-o')
hold on
loglog(n, 0.5 * err(end) * (n / n(end)) .^ (-4), '--')
xlabel("n");  ylabel("inf-norm error")
title("Convergence of AB4")
legend("AB4", "O(n^{-4})", location="southwest");
We will solve the problem first with the implicit AM2 method using

children.html: n=200n=200n=200

children.value: Now we repeat the process using the explicit AB4 method.
Once the solution starts to take off, the AB4 result goes catastrophically wrong.
We hope that AB4 will converge in the limit

children.html: h→0h\to 0h→0

children.value: , so let’s try using more steps.
So AB4, which is supposed to be
accurate than AM2, actually needs something like 8 times as many steps to get a reasonable-looking answer!
We’ll measure the error at the time

children.html: t=1t=1t=1

children.value: The error starts out promisingly, but things explode from there. A graph of the last numerical attempt yields a clue.

clf
semilogy(t, abs(u))
xlabel("t");  ylabel("|u(t)|")
title(("LIAF solution"));
It’s clear that the solution is growing exponentially in time.
